150525592.review:
After over 1,200 hours, and potentially more in Facerig I really can't recommend this anymore. There are far too many crashes when you add and remove devices to the software and really isn't as intuitive as it used to be. I think that it's an unfortunate circumstance of technology catching up *VERY* quickly.

I've previously spoken to support about my issues with the software - which didn't really lead to any results and, at one point I was also paying a subscription, but it quickly all lead to just an intuitive mess that I really didn't want to deal with further.

Vtuber Studio for me is the king of Live2D, is free and has very few limitations. The moment I touched it, I lost all motivation to continue using Animaze. It might be fun for a novel purpose perhaps, but I don't think its quite caught up with everything else. The fact that Vtuber studio does not crash at all when I insert my tablet for art streams and doesn't fuss when I switch monitors - the technical aspects are really what hold Animaze back.

I think the app can be improved, but it would probably require a lot more work than the developers nessicarily want to invest - so I will just go with what is working for me rather than what isn't.
150525592.developer_response:
Hello Zephyr,
Thank you for the time with Animaze, and the candid feedback, much appreciated!


We are always working to improve. 
You might have noticed that there was a pause in updates recently, that's also because we are right now fundamentally re-assessing how we monitor, measure, and handle these kinds of hard-to-catch issues, and also coding in ways that make the users more aware of potential problems. Hopefully, that will bring the issue affecting you in the light, and get it fixed for everyone. 

For edge cases that happen when adding/removing hardware devices, or changing monitors, we do need specific details about the context that caused the issue to occur, log files, and as much additional information (sent to support[@]animaze[.]us) as possible so we can reproduce the issue on a dev machine. 


_________________________________

On a more general, mission-related note, unlike most avatar software, Animaze does not use a ready-made corporate/commercial gaming engine to put your avatar on screen. 
It would be indeed easier/faster to do so, (and that path should be explored, as it is, by many great apps), but there are several reasons why we are exploring a different, more challenging path, an indie engine path. 
This is spurred by the fact that some of the corporate engines are partially owned by entities (including official investment branches of autocratic governments) that have a problematic stance on free speech and minority rights, (not to mention AI art);  their runtimes start to collect more data from their users as times goes by.

Strictly for gaming/entertainment, perhaps that has no implications, but avatars and avatar identities are a tool for communication, free speech and its independence is of paramount importance here. An indie engine alternative safeguards from the potential influence of engine shareholder-dictated policies. That, as we saw this year, can happen, unilaterally, retroactively, and suddenly. In an engine-monopoly scenario, that can be scary.
Staying independent on the engine side, and not using that very tantalizing pool of "free" work, means that the Animaze engine does not benefit from the vast commercial engine QA department and all the pre-written plugins for commercial engines, but, in doing so, stays independent. The price of that independence is that need to build and test a LOT more in-house, often with considerably fewer resources.


In the end though, as hard as we work, and no matter how many innovative features we were "first to market" with in the last 9 years, we know that independence from large companies aspect is not considered *that* important by many, and it is inevitable that there will be users who are not happy with some aspects of the Animaze indie engine, or at the speed at which we can move independently. 


Cheers and happy streaming, no matter the platform you may use from now on :)

Hola "petete_el_makin"
(Disculpas, lo siguiente está traducido automáticamente.)


Lamentamos que tenga problemas al importar algunos modelos personalizados.
Sin embargo, las soluciones son simples y funcionan mejor cuando hay diálogo.

Animaze utiliza un motor independiente personalizado y admite muchos formatos de modelos. El equipo de Animaze en este momento está formado por solo tres personas; En algunos casos extremos que aún no hemos probado, los modelos personalizados pueden causar problemas o incluso bloquear la importación.
Si la gente nos envía esos modelos por correo electrónico, normalmente investigamos y parcheamos nuestro importador para que no vuelva a fallar.

Incluso si no lo haces si quieres enviar los modelos, todavía hay mucho que puedes hacer.

1. En lugar de importar directamente a la aplicación en la "vía rápida", es mejor importar a través del Editor Animaze; permite detectar el error en el modelo antes de que llegue a la aplicación.

2. Si un modelo incorrecto ingresó a la aplicación y ahora la aplicación falla, simplemente elimine el modelo de Data\Resources.
También puedes "restablecer los valores de fábrica" ​​de la aplicación y todas sus configuraciones, como se describe aquí:
http://steamcommunity.com/app/1364390/discussions/0/3878220223856004404/#c3878220223856143849

Para otros problemas de soporte, escríbanos a support[@]animaze[.]us o consulte la información en https://www.animaze.us/manual/import-custom-models

¡Saludos y feliz transmisión!

148905565.developer_response:
Hello Gamez And More,

I see you have more than a thousand hours logged on Animaze.
Were you using the free version and it was okay, and then when you changed your sub status something happened? There could be some error in your config files, but it should be easy to address by resetting the app to "factory settings".

To be able to help we will need the app logs sent in via email:  https://www.animaze.us/faq/tech/gatherlogs


Also if, after sending in the logs,  you want to simply reset the app to "factory defaults" this is how you do it

-Go to <animazeInstallDir>\Data\ and delete  AppPreferences.json and Preferences.json and cacert.pem.
-This resets most configurations to default (key binds, quick scenes, camera options, etc.) maybe one of those creates an issue.
- Do a "verify integrity" through Steam.
-Open Animaze.

Cheers!

147946295.developer_response:
Hello JZCS,

Thank you!

If you need advice in lowering RAM usage, it would be helpful if you could send us an email with details at support[@]animaze[.]us with context, for us to be able to help better.

By default, Animaze shouldn't take up much RAM (not if used on defaults), but it can get higher in some usage scenarios if the users wish it so.

- when custom-made avatars with excessively high-resolution textures are used/imported.
- when the resolution sliders on any dynamic textures or broadcast video surfaces are dialed all the way up to 4k or 8k resolutions
- when too many RAM pre-cached quick scenes are being set up 

We are not putting low limits on these, as some users use Animaze for video production on beefy video rigs, and not streaming, and they need all that power and RAM usage to do their 4k/8k rendering, but we do hope streaming users, in performance sensitive scenarios,  make sensible performance choices when creating their set-up, and don't crank up the sliders to the max.

147647774.developer_response:
Hello Wondersilly!

Most casual users have never had to use a Windows system with two webcams on it, before installing an avatar app. That is usually the source of most initial confusion around operating an avatar app properly.

After installing an avatar app, you have at least two different webcam devices on your system: your old real one, and a new virtual one, so you can appear as an avatar on video conferencing apps.

The problems are trivial once you learn your ABCs about how Windows works with two webcam devices. Once you know to set what you want to use as a  "default Windows webcam"  and what is "exclusive webcam access", things are easy-peasy.

Cheers, and happy streaming!

Hello Professisonal Amaterur, 

We love Facerig too, as it was our initial "baby" and we poured all our love and heart into it, but to remain objective here is a comparison video with a ported old gen  avatar. Look how much more natural the Animaze one moves and speaks.
Had we done this video with Animaze-gen native avatar like Noah the lion cub, and not a ported one like Fluffo, the movements would have been even more expressive on Animaze's side. The goal with Animaze was not to get stuck on old avatars and nostalgia land, but to create something new, better, more streamlined and easier to use alternative, and move forward into the future.

https://youtu.be/sJ4wijtsCjM?si=YLj-sZP6MZe3mXXS




Just as Witcher 2 was better than Witcher 1, even when there are hardcore Witcher 1 fans who swear that Witcher 1 was a  better game, so is Animaze compared with FaceRig. Just like Witcher 2 couldn't' t have been "grafted" on top of Witcher 1, neither could Animaze, being built 5 years later on a brand new engine,  be grafted on top of FaceRig's old engine.
 
The great thing about them remaining two different apps, is that you get to chose which one you want to use every day (Facerig was not taken away form any of its old users, who bought in in 2014 to 2022, and, in spite of its old age, is being used by about 500 streamers each day, today on Steam). 

Here is a live case study:
 
Puff Puff, Powered by Animaze  with its 4.7 million followers on Tiktok is among the very few, quite possibly the only Virtual Being worldwide with high engagement that reaches those numbers of millions of followers, and does so  with a stock Animaze avatar and an inexpensive app,  and, more importantly,  no huge streaming talent management agency and marketing budgets behind him, like most large agency-backed VTubers have.  https://www.tiktok.com/@itspuffpuff/

145560350.developer_response:
Hello Fenggar,

Thank you for the feedback, much appreciated!
There are many ways to track with Animaze: https://www.animaze.us/manual/appmanual/trackers


The smartphone type that would probably be a net positive over webcam-tracking, is a TrueDepth-enabled iPhone via the iPhone tracking bridge (ideally connected via a USB cable). 


Using other smartphones right now (unless you are using a VMC phone app - but that's more advanced)  means that you probably have to rely on a run-of-the-mill "use my smartphone as a webcam" app. Those can indeed introduce too many compression artifacts on your video feed, stream the video unevenly over the wifi to your PC,  congest the wifi (probably the shakes you mention), and have quite a detrimental effect on tracking quality, even when compared with an inexpensive USB webcam. 

Cheers, and happy streaming!

Thank you Elsixen,

It is nice for all the effort we put into the avatar emotion engine to be seen and appreciated. 

The reason we have put all these options in is because we are firm believers that avatars need to transcend their initial status as simple "stage puppets" with mostly rubber stamp expressions and gain the ability to become genuine alternate identities, capable of true emotional communication and emotional connection. 

For that, the system needs to start simple (can be made to work in "rubber stamp expression" mode if you want it to) but also have a high enough complexity ceiling to handle human communication nuance.

144545354.developer_response:
Hello Harry, 

You seem to be using the "preview video" feature, or using mpeg encoding to get a  final video, which is not the recommended way to create good videos with Animaze.  https://www.animaze.us/manual/video/ded-window ;  When exporting a video performance, using an uncompressed image sequence or mp4 will be better than an mpeg preview. 

Animaze uses a different engine than Facerig, and indeed the best-looking avatars are the new ones, like the Personas or Noah the Lion Cub and his friends, not the legacy engine ones like Danny.  

A side-by-side video done with Noah in Animaze vs Danny in Facerig, using a modern tracking method like the iPhone Arkit in Animaze, or even the latest webcam tracker with OVR audio lipsync,  if done right (  https://www.animaze.us/manual/calibration ),  is over in Animaze's favor, faster than you can say "Peter Piper picked a pack of pickled peppers" and see the avatar's lips move :). 
Here is one of our older internal video comparisons to give you perspective, captured in real-time, even on defaults, on Fluffo, himself a ported avatar, with nothing customized on tracking, just a proper one-button calibration, and same video and audio input used for both.
https://youtu.be/sJ4wijtsCjM

Facerig Fluffo has a bit of a psychotic vibe like he might stab me in a dark alleyway for drug money, while Animaze Fluffo, while not perfect, is far more friendly and approachable and articulates all the spoken words far more clearly. The differences in Animaze's favor are even greater if you use Animaze native assets, like Noah or the Personas, or start using the Advanced tracking settings for fine-tuning, to any degree.


Using Animaze correctly does require some usage flow changes, playing beyond the defaults, like the  "studio gray" initial light setup, and adjusting the default motion capture settings to your liking, but when you do that you'll find it has a higher expressivity/naturalness ceiling than FaceRig did.


Cheers, and happy streaming!

139897358.developer_response:
Hello gotyczech,

The free tier watermark is placed on the edges of the image (not the center) specifically so that it does not make the free app unusable, for those who insist on staying on free and/or can't spend anything on it. It is a lower barrier to entry than a mandatory upfront cost.

It is no secret and no accident;  we've made sure that you can stay on the free tier if you must. OBS cropping has been around since the start. 

Please remember that the free version is not ad-supported. It can exist and continue to be developed and upgraded only due to free tier users eventually upgrading to paying customers and using the full-featured version. 


Most VTubing initiatives rely on people spending a few dollars on the software too, (not just hundreds of dollars on custom VTubing models). 
Today is a particularly sad day as another notable VTubing app has just announced a cease in operations as they were unable to make ends meet for the last three years: https://steamcommunity.com/app/1207050/eventcomments/3820788154611143753?snr=1_2108_9__2107 . Like with any initiative closing, the Vtubing world is slightly less bright for it.

Cheers, & happy streaming!

138867979.developer_response:
Hello. 
Because Animaze is more complex, some aspects may have a bit more of a learning curve. It does have a higher price than its FaceRig counterpart, but it vastly surpasses Facerig in many ways. 


Here is a personal top 10 features to consider (most can be evaluated using the free version):


1. Support for IPhone face tracking (in any side-by-side comparison it surpasses anything that was ever possible on Facerig with its webcam-only tracker).
2. In-app Persona Avatar Creator - an inexpensive way to get a highly customized avatar in minutes, with no additional cost.
3. In-app retexturing (including with Spout2 Live feeds, for set-ups with in-world live screens a la CodeMiko)
4. VRM import  support (both 0.0 and 1.0, including PerfectSync) and GLB /Ready Player Me support to vastly expand avatar library size options  (the old Facerig engine and toolset did not support blend shapes at all, and VRM PerfectSync models nor Ready Playe Me would have never been ever possible there)
5. Twitch Actions/ Twitch integration
6. VMC protocol support (for things like Webcam-based hand tracking body tracking,  or filming camera tracking for Virtual Production Studio scenarios. 
7. Far more face input emotion controls (78+), and far more body controls.
8. Generalized animation system for all humanoids.
9. Proper multiplayer, over the internet.
10. Advanced camera motion controls (with optional camera interpolation between Quickscenes).

The list could go on,  Animaze API, support for Sony Mocopi,  Nvidia Maxine, Streamdeck, Tobii Tracker, Voicemod, Holographic display output with the Dreamoc Display, Hybrid Avatars, Live2D backdrops, Live2D freeform/advanced parameters set, one button import for Live2d (no more editing FaceRig CFG files), Full Body Motion Capture suit support with Perception Neuron PN3,  and many more. If there are features that did not make the jump, those are in general more fringe features that we noticed were not getting really any meaningful use in Facerig.


Former Facerig users considering the upgrade should only spend anything on Animaze if they genuinely are convinced is better and appreciate the cost being fair for all the new features, otherwise, the old Facerig license is still there for them to use today (just without any further update warranties due to its frozen 2017-level engine).

Cheers, and Happy Streaming!

136918045.developer_response:
Hello leetNightshade

The NVidia Maxine tracker is, as mentioned in the UI, not yet a main way of using Animaze but rather an alpha integration. The feedback is valuable, thank you for providing it.
Animaze is currently meant to be used primarily via the Visage Face Tracker, or the iPhone face tracker (if you have a TrueDepth iPhone). For hands/body there is the Leap Motion, VMC interface, or, for high-end results,  the Perception Neuron motion capture suit for the body.



More detailed help on motion capture set-up follows below:
Syncing inputs from different sensor paths, (Audio trackers and Video trackers) can be a bit tricky, especially for folks who are new to motion capture/performance capture, more info is provided here: https://www.animaze.us/manual/calibration 

In the advanced tracking settings or in the Overrides sections there are tracking settings that deal specifically with typical limitations of consumer face trackers, like the one you mentioned (tracking confidence decreasing when you turn your head to the side), to avoid the "spazzing out", but they need to be tuned appropriately for each individual set-up. 

Drinking from a cup and other frequent activities that block the sensor's view of your face features is not an activity that would be recommended during performance capture, by any mo-cap technician.

Cheers, and happy streaming!

134696649.review: AFTER DELETING AND UNISTALLING IT IT STILL COMESS UP WITH A CAMEREA AT THE BOTTOM RIGHT OF MY SCREEN HOW DO IL FIX THIS
134696649.developer_response:
Hello :)

The odds are that two things happened: 

You had Geforce Experience Hud Overlay (or a similar webcam overlay software) still toggled on AND it was set to source the Animaze virtual webcam at the moment when you chose to uninstall Animaze. 

That (or perhaps something else that was using the Animaze Virtual webcam driver) likely prevented the Animaze virtual driver from uninstalling normally as it was actively being used at the time. 

What you need to do is likely: 
1. Step 1: If active,  turn off the Geforce Experience Webcam HUD  overlay (see the HUD layout section) - The default shortcut for its config menu is Alt+Z.
https://www.nvidia.com/en-us/geforce/news/geforce-experience-brodcasting-tutorial/
(or any other similar program that shows the webcam overlay on your desktop, which may try to source the Animaze Virtual Webcam video feed). 

2. Uninstall the Animaze Virtual webcam driver from the Device Manager by following the official manual driver uninstall guide here.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2643121919

Cheers!

If our assumption was not correct, further context and questions can be sent via email to support[@]animaze[.]us

130945991.review: I downloaded this a while ago and completely forgot about it after messing around with it for like 20 minutes but recently it put a little box in the bottom right of my screen that overlays over anything that's there and I can't figure out how to get rid of it. I reset my PC and it was still there and I tried to delete the application but I can't since it isn't a game it's just free to play through steam. Please if anyone experienced this problem tell me how I can fix it because it completely ruined everything that I have been trying to do on my computer for the past couple of weeks and I can't find a way to get rid of it.
130945991.developer_response:
Hello Jojo, 

The HUD overlays usually have very little to do with Animaze itself (Animaze does not add any such overlays on its own); more likely they are displayed by a GPU webcam overlay app that is happening to be sourcing either a not valid webcam or the Animaze webcam in a "turned off" state.

The default Windows webcam is normally auto-set by Windows to the most recently installed webcam; that is why if no other webcams were installed after Animaze, then the Animaze Virtual webcam is probably right now your "default" Windows webcam. 

You likely need to go into those GPU overlay hud app settings and point to the webcam you want, or simply turn off the webcam overlay altogether.

For the NVidia Geforce experience: press Alt+z > go to settings > go to hud layout > turn off the layout. Other overlay software would naturally be different, but the principle is the same.
Keep us posted via support channels (support[@]animaze[.]us) or on the forum.

121153107.review:
There are reasons why this software is not popular within established virtual streamers, despite being a pioneer of low-cost avatar solution. No, it's not because of their business model and I'm not going to touch that in my review because others are slamming them down already. This is more of an opinion to the company itself. All this time, Holotech are focusing on the wrong thing.

The biggest mistakes they made is not focusing to the CREATORS. Anyone who ever created models for Facerig and Animaze (2D or 3D alike) agreed the experience was painful. Holotech are refusing to use popular engine like Unity or Unreal for the sake of being 'independent' and pushed us creators to use a bunch of half baked toolsets with worst usability compared to modern 3D authoring software (seriously, Animaze Editor gives me a vibe of Valve Hammer Editor from the 90s). In turns, my creators peers are refusing to use it. Why should they waste their time to learn a very specific software that goes against established knowledge of working with Unity/Unreal? They dodged a bullet there because half of Animaze issues tracker are filled with complaints of their buggy, lack of foolproof Editor.

Their competitor got it right by making the experience delightful to CREATORS FIRST, then users second. They are introducing bunch of features that are not only useful for users, but also exciting for the creators. Simply put, they are able to establish a COMMUNITY. Bunch of people who are willing to help and support each other, with tools developed by community to the community. Holotech have no such luxury, so they are facing to different direction by catering to general users. But then they are directly competing to the bigger behemoth like Facebook, Snap, and Tiktok, who are already comes up with their own AR face tracking and avatar solution. Their attempt at developing mobile filters app failed miserably. Hell, they don’t even stand a chance against VRM format.

I held out myself from writing this review because I want to see how Animaze develops but after almost a year with bland updates, I’m compelled to write this out. I’ve been creating models for Facerig since 2015, went through a lot of false promises from them (stalled Facerig updates because “our engineering bandwidth are full for new SDK we are developing”, multi platform, avatar marketplace, etc). Maybe at this point the company are just waiting to be absorbed by bigger fish in the ocean. Until then, hold out on your Animaze licenses.
121153107.developer_response:
Hello PixelVertice,
Thank you for the feedback! It has been almost two years. 

PufPuff using Animaze and a stock avatar has a whooping 3.8 million followers on Tiktok (and is even selling plushies),  and this meteoric success is on a platform seen by many as the social network of the future. 
https://www.tiktok.com/@itspuffpuff 
That avatar content was done with the simple Animaze free iOS app, and Animaze stock avatar content, it vastly surpasses any other Virtual beings on the platform, even the ones with an agency and spending tons on custom content. It might even surpass summed out accounts on entire top vTubing agencies in terms of Tiktok followers.


We're really good at opening new roads for the future, just like we did for Twitch VTubing in the past; and with PuffPuff being so massive just with stock Animaze content, can you imagine if we were to work together again to improve the Editor, how much further this could go?
Our platform is open to all avatar types, and the multiplayer update even allows them to be in the same room together.
Our door was and is always open.

117189674.review:
So Facerig was a quality product that was well worth buying.  I was even willing to shell out money for the characters they created.  I would have even considered paying for character creation services.

And I was equally interested in Animaze, and was willing to pay for it.  I was on the upgrade screen, look at the $100 price, and was about to click the button, when I noticed a word at the top of the window.....  "SUBSCRIPTION".

When I had my furnace installed, no one said that I had to pay the HVAC people a monthly fee for the rest of my life or the furnace stopped working.

I don't know why programmers or companies, think that they can write a bit of software, and then have someone pay them for the rest of their lives, while they do nothing.

"Well what about bug fixes??"  Yeah, and Ford has never issued a recall to fix a broken part, and demanded I pay a subscription fee to replace their bad part.

"Well what about new avatars?"   Yeah, and I am more than willing to pay for new avatars that I actually want.   But reality is, I'm going to use one avatar on my videos, and never use any others.  So why should I pay you for the rest of my life, so you can make an avatar I never use?

To anyone reading this, I'm sure Animaze is one of the best software packages on the internet right now for this sort of service.   But the reality is, it's not worth paying for the rest of your life.   There are a half dozen other software packages that do exactly the same thing, and are free, or have a flat fee.  Both of which is better than a "Pay us until you die" subscription model.

Pretty sad.  Almost paid them $100, and instead they get nothing.  And to think they had a kickstarter, and now they are demanding the people who supported them, pay for the rest of their lives to use their software.  Seems rather evil to me.
117189674.developer_response:
Hello  Sayōnara!

Cheers and Happy Streaming!

116356708.developer_response:
Hello RemySkullix

The windows default webcam - the webcam device that most browsers on your system will try to use by default -  is auto-set by Windows to the most recently installed webcam device. This is not specific to avatar software, it happens whenever a new webcam device is installed.

If you want to remove any newly installed webcam device, go to the Windows Device Manager, right-click on its name and either disable it or uninstall it, and Opera and any other webcam software on your system, should again use your old default. 

Here is the full Animaze uninstall guide (you probably had skipped the device removal part): 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2643121919 


The Animaze face tracking and all its settings (including iPhone-based tracking) are available on the free tier, the face tracking quality can be sampled and fine-tuned before any money is required.


Happy streaming!

115852172.developer_response:
Hello,

Regarding the OBS issue. You can easily use a transparent background by just adding 1 filter to the OBS scene.
Here are some guides that might help you:
https://www.animaze.us/faq/tech/obseffects
https://www.animaze.us/faq/tech/transparency

If you are on a paid tier, then the quickest and most performance-effective way to get a true alpha channel to OBS is to use the spout2 plugin broadcast option from the Dedicated Render Window options.

Regarding the .fbx support, you should be able to import .fbx avatars as long as those follow our documentation. You can find everything here: https://www.animaze.us/manual/gettingstarted3d/howtousethedocumentation

Also, if you have any questions or issues you can always contact us at support[@]animaze[.]us or just join our Discord: https://animaze.tv/discord

Splendid piece of software, gentlemen. As a former United States Marine, I am definitely about packing the right gear to accomplish whatever the mission at hand demands. Animaze has forged us a powerful tool to accomplish that, tailor made to just about any virtual interaction ecosphere out there. The Animaze Editor is streamlined but packs enough punch to handle compositing, debugging, and particle effects. I am just beginning to find my own feet in the Editor now, with the aid of the concise documentation and tireless support from their team on Discord, answering user questions. I do love the expressiveness and range of emotion all avatars are capable of, in the Animaze SDK landscape. Even if it means a few more bones to pick and a little extra work on the retargeting end, the payoff is nothing less than the promised land beyond the Uncanny Valley, Hard Chargers, so it is definitely worthwhile. I do believe that we are out here in the jungle, swinging our machetes, on the bleeding edge of the future of human communication. I shit thee not. Thank you, Dev team @ Animaze for blazing a trail and for being gracious enough to invite us along to help broaden the path a bit. Excelsior!

What I don't like the subscription model, which is what I am referring to as a 'cash grab'. (Facerig, which does predate vtubing getting big is not sub-based, which you already know.)

3. Being a pioneer in a field doesn't mean you're immune from making missteps, nor does it mean your competition can't do better. If Facerig had gotten an update to support VRMs,  people wouldn't be upset. But Animaze...

4. You can use the free tier to test if iPhone-based tracking will work for you, sure. But if you actually want to stream with Animaze, you need the subscription, and I already commented on the subscription model.

5. Are you trying to imply I'm not a paying customer? LOL. The lack of recent hours is because I moved on from the app, *after having used it with a plus-tier sub for a few streams*.  And I did actually open the app recently - to cancel my sub. I left this review after uninstalling because I was making space for another game I'd bought. 

In conclusion. Was I a little harsh? Yeah, and I shouldn't have been. But I stand by my point that sub-based models feel like a cash-grab, especially when they were introduced after vtubing got big.

 Animaze is one of the few custom engine apps that has coded in a custom engine implementation for VRM/Vroid, to help it grow beyond the Unity/Unreal ecosystem.  

If someone new to this space, maybe a user who wants a non-anime character,  wants to "test the water" with no risk, this way they can get started right now, with zero dollars being needed upfront, and zero wait time to have a custom character made.  
Commissioning custom work is still available if you want it, but you now also have a 100% de-risked way to see if avatars (both anime or not) are right for you.

Do not spend any money, before you've done all comparisons and you think it is fully deserved.



Cheers!

In yearly terms:  it is only after the Animaze content makes you 6000 USD yearly, that you would need to get the 100 USD yearly sub. (60x return on investment or better) .


If you are not getting the 25x or 60x ROI or better, you can stay on the free tier, or if you want to be a paying customer who supports the development instead of a free user,  you have the 20 USD per year Plus plan. 


Cheers!

Overall a recommend, with some caveats.
* Most of the stuff you would want to actively use it are paywalled.  This is 'ok' as "seeing if this will even work" is still free.  I feel the need to call this out as a lot of the negative reviews are based on this paywall and things that have either changed since release or outright whining that the developer should want to make money for doing work.
* I'm using this on an  i7-8565U and I had to step down the quality quite a bit to kill the 0.3s lag I was seeing.  It was enough that it just didn't match my audio.  It showed 9/16 gigs of ram used and 50% CPU usage.  It was plugged-in.  If the recommended of an i5 6th-gen is accurate, this should have slayed this without issue.  It. did. not.  I'm a wee-bit disappointed in this as it should have used more CPU instead of making me turn it down.   Like if it was pegged at 80-100%, sure...   but it was 50% so it was sparing room for what?  It's 2022 and your multicore game better be on-point.
* The paywall is like 20 bucks a year (currently) unless you make north of 500 bucks a month streaming.  This seems more than reasonable, IMHO.
* The lip tracking wasn't nearly as expressive as I was hoping it would be.  I need to play with it, but I tried the trackers, my webcam isn't a total slouch... it was just not good.
107349893.developer_response:
Hello Bipster!

Thank you for the thoughtful review. 
Animaze is a living product and we are constantly looking to improve it on each release, so thank you for this feedback, it is appreciated.

The good news is that there are plenty ways to adjust the CPU load. 
The most frequent settings that we see dialed up and that may cause higher than needed CPU occupancy  (without providing a lot of tangible benefits to make the increase worthwhile) are increasing resolution and/or FPS  of the input webcam stream (640p or 720p should be enough, full HD is overkill), and the resolution/FPS  of the outgoing virtual webcam stream.
 
Unfortunately the i7-8565U you mention (U stands for ultra low voltage, typically used in low power Ultrabooks) in spite of being newer and sporting the "i7" prefix actually less powerful than the i5 listed under the minimal requirements for Animaze, which is a desktop grade processor.  More detailed information of what the letter suffixes mean can be found here: https://www.quora.com/What-are-the-differences-between-U-M-QM-MQ-and-HQ-processors-of-Intel-to-consider-when-buying-a-laptop

The i7-8565U is meant to function on 15 watts of power and below, while the desktop is one meant to run on 75 watts of power. The Ultrabook CPU does do an impressive amount of computation within those 15 watts (it is more power efficient) , but it is still a CPU achitectured around battery efficiency, and not a desktop high power CPU. 

Details below, compared with the desktop grade processor listed as minimum requirement:
https://cpu.userbenchmark.com/Compare/Intel-Core-i7-8565U-vs-Intel-Core-i5-4570/m591977vs2770 the i5 is 12 % faster in terms of effective speed.

Ultrabook systems built with Ultra Low Voltage processors also almost never have dedicated GPU's, they are relying on the integrated Intel UHD video card. That also tends to clock in below (in terms of raw performance) what we list as the the minimal GPU requirement. Being an integrated GPU (and thus not having its own separate heat management solution), can further compound performance issue by causing thermal throttling (for both CPU and GPU) making the system stay at a lower clock speed. This too may contribute to less than ideal performance you are seeing.

On the default settings Animaze should take about 1 GB of RAM and about 20%~24% of an average modern desktop CPU. That CPU load can go even lower if the face tracking (typically an intensive CPU task the more details on the face are tracked) is offloaded to an external device such as in iPhone. In that case the total CPU load will hover around 8 to 10%.

Memory usage can shoot up if using a lot of pre-cashed quick scenes and the asset count can quickly ramp up, normally it should be around 1 to 1.5 Gigs of RAM without pre-cached quick scenes.


We have a fair amount of performance tips and tricks listed on the animaze.us website in the FAQ section and we are also active on the forums and our Discord server with more performance related advices. If you are seeing unexplainable high numbers (on CPU, GPU or memory) you can also send in your app logs and dxdiag logs with proper context to support[@]animaze[.]us for us to figure out that was atypical, and why you are seeing more resource load than normal. There could be things that we need to tweak too.

Hello, GreyDev1l. Thank you for your feedback regarding the tracking of Animaze and its overall performance. It's really useful for us as we're constantly improving Animaze based upon the feedback that we receive. With that being said, the tracking in Animaze suffers in performance when the environment is not well lit. 106326239.developer_response:
Hello -=LaTe®aLuS=-

Thank you so much for the feedback. 
The promo video is indeed done by someone with no beard.

Beards or anything that's occluding a full view of the face will always be a challenge for face motion capture, and cause more instability.
This is true everywhere marker-less motion capture and beards meet (in motion capture studios that deal with marker-less face emotion capture, beards are almost non existent on acting talent).
 
Some of it can be addressed to an extent in various ways:
- (by sacrificing some responsiveness)  via increasing the filtering in the advanced tracking settings, 
- by using the iPhone tracking instead of webcam tracking, 
- some have seen success also by using an IP cam with IR light instead of RGB. In the end the face tracking with partial occlusion (beards) will always be more unstable than facial tracking with no occlusion (no beard). 
We've also seen people with more "lumberjack" beards get improved results when trying to get the webcam to see their real jawline (behind the beard) by  wearing a turtleneck that was going up on the neck close to the jaw, and the beard going under it. In the end though, visual based mocap will always be more unstable when trying to track any part of the face that is hidden/occluded from the camera.

105126965.review:
*Edit*  Animaze now offers a perpetual option for personal use! This instantly makes it the most practical, polished, and user friendly solution for Virtual Avatars. A huge thank you to the Animaze team for listening to the feedback and finally making the change, even if it did take this long.  I'm more then happy to continue purchasing upgraded versions of Animaze as long as those licenses don't expire. Below is my orignal review before the new perpetual license options were added.

This is a tough one for me.  My reason for not recommending really comes down to being forced to rent instead of buy if you want to remove the watermark and use a couple other features that could be useful.  That being said, at the time of writing this and assuming they don't change the way the watermark works, you can technically circumvent it in OBS.  To be clear, I would only use Animaze for personal use in video calls and maybe an unmonetized stream or two.  I have no desire to make money as a streamer, but I think if you are, then its completely fair and you shouldn't have a problem paying a subscription for commercial use.  Its not fair for personal users like myself though and we shouldn't have the obnoxious eye sore forced on us.

When Animaze first came out it had restrictions on the free version that would have definitely kept me away without a perpetual option to unlock them, such as a 90 minute time limit to use the virtual camera, but they've since removed a lot of those restrictions and its actually quite usable as is if you don't want to pay a subscription and are just using it to make video calls more fun, like me. That's why I've finally been tempted to give it a chance.  I don't trust it to stay that way though and that is why I wholeheartedly would recommend you look elsewhere for a virtual webcam.  I would even say pick up FaceRig while you still can (to the end of 2021).  The UI isn't as nice and clean looking but it still has all the features I think most people would care about.  Custom 3D avatars, LeapMotion support, green screen background, and most importantly NO WATERMARK!

I actually don't mind supporting software with a monthly contribution (I donate $10 every month to Blender) but when its forced and I have no option to buy perpetual access then I'm instantly turned off.  I still use Adobe CS6 and will switch to freeware before every paying a penny for Creative Cloud.  The reason is it takes a way the incentive for them to keep improving the software.  If the only option for people to unintrusively use your software is to rent, you have a guaranteed stream of income and no real reason to add anything new.  I'll likely end up going back to FaceRig since I don't see them offering a perpetual version of Animaze any time soon if at all.  

The improvements in Animaze are basically all in the cleaner looking UI and the FacRig engine and tracking still looks pretty close to the same in my eyes.  There is an Anubis avatar in Animaze that I really like but I can always make my own for FaceRig if I end up really missing him.  If they back track on some of the restrictions they've removed or change the watermark so it can't be removed in OBS, I'll definitely be saying adios.

I know this ended up a bit long but I wanted to actually sound constructive and not just talk down to Holotech in a fit of rage over their new licensing strategy.  I don't agree with the way they've executed it but do think they've put some hard work into making an improved version of what was formally FacRig.  I just hope they can eventually see why opinions like this matter and aren't going to change.

Definitely not normal values, most people are seeing values around 20%, on average machines, not 90% (90% is a shocking number to be sure).  If using iPhone tracking, it can go as low as just 8%.

Cheers!

102724823.developer_response:
Hello Asrya Kino!

Thank you for this feedback, we read it all (both positive and negative) and we always try to take that to heart and do better!


1. On the replacing topic:
Animaze is replacing Facerig after seven years just in the sense that it will serve the ever-connected Metaverse avatar future, as a live service, far better than Facerig ever could as an offline tool.
Facerig itself is not disappearing from your library: it is a standalone tool and can continue to be used just as before, (ideally indefinitely) in parallel with Animaze. 
Animaze existing does not take anything away from the current FaceRig.


2. Facerig's support ending after seven years.
Facerig's fate took a dark turn three-four years after its 2014 launch when resources were running out in 2017-2018, it looked like soon there would be no way to pay for significant art and programming hours to go into it anymore.

Animaze dev. effort was started separately in 2018, helped by external investment from institutional investors on a different Metaverse-centric paradigm, to better serve the future and avoid the mistakes of the past. 


3. Simultaneous 2 PC Steam use is possible:
We hear you on the need to stream Animaze in parallel with a Steam game and solutions are in place. 
- On the same PC: starting a game and Animaze should work at the same time, by default.
- If using two different PC's and the same Steam account on both: just start Steam in "Offline mode" on the Animaze PC, and Animaze should still start and work with all its sub features available (if you are a sub). If you join the Discord we can walk you through those steps.

In the future, a non-Steam version of Animaze will exist too, to make things even easier. 


4. Last and not least: we cannot legally "sell to own" if we do not have the legal right to do so. 
A lot of technology layers and libraries required to bring the best avatar experience for the Metaverse, particularly face tracking ones, are also being licensed to us as a service (very few organizations in 2021-2022  license key technology like high-end face tracking to users "to own forever" - things were a bit different in 2014). 
That is one of the reasons why legally we may only license these tech libraries to you as a service; on the flip side the service does have a free tier though, and the paid tiers are optional and inexpensive.

We are always available to discuss all these things, including calibration tips and tricks, on our Discord (check out the Steam forum for Discord join data).

102697376.developer_response:
Hello KannaCrossing!

Thank you for the thoughtful review and the nice words!
We do indeed provide a lot of tracking controls, and we track a lot of face details so that everyone can tune and get their avatar performance just right; we are glad to see it is appreciated.

On the note of performance: while on certain settings it can be high, the good news is that the performance footprint is largely configurable. 

There are settings that, if dialed up,  can make Animaze take a lot more CPU. While we don't know what settings you are currently using, one example that we have seen rather frequently is people opting to use a 1080p input camera feed (or even 4k!) over a more normal 640x480 or a 720p. An increased resolution of the input webcam feed needs a *lot* more CPU, without offering a lot of tracking benefits. 
It is best to keep that in mind when optimizing for performance.

We have a fair bit of information in the FAQ section like this article here: https://www.animaze.us/faq/tech/improvegpu
... but you can also join the Animaze Discord (link in the forums here on Steam) or write to support[@]animaze[.]us to ask more specific performance questions. 

Warm regards!

The Animaze watermark can ONLY display on the Animaze Virtual Webcam output or on Animaze's Secondary Render window.

- Facerig continues to exist separated from Animaze, you can continue to use it, just that its support is ending after a respectable seven years.

In terms of art content (separated from feature content) - it was never about the stock art content being the only content. 97939598.developer_response:
Hello Tsuyu_Asui


Sorry to hear you encountered difficulties. Here is what most likely happened:

Whenever you install a new webcam driver, the Windows OS by default assumes that this latest one is the one you want that as your "default webcam",  that communication apps will use by default. You can change what the "default Windows webcam"  is via the Control Pannel.

In your case, after installing Animaze,  the last installed webcam driver was the Animaze Virtual Camera driver, so that's why Zoom was using it by default (nothing was forced though - you could have picked a different camera with the Zoom camera selector at any time).

What maybe threw you off was the  Windows "one-app one-camera limit". In Windows, to prevent hackers to spy on you via your webcam,  there is this limitation at the OS level: Only one app can access a camera device at a given time. So if you were already using your real camera as a tracking source in Animaze, no other software could access that physical webcam too, as it was already in use. If you had first closed Animaze, then the other apps should have been able to again access the physical webcam.  

All the above assume that OS webcam access permissions were correctly set up.

Now after uninstalling Animaze, it could be that the Animaze Virtual Webcam driver is still on your system (for some reason the uninstall script did not remove it). 
You can easily remove it manually, using the Device Manager. 
You just need to look for the Animaze Virtual Webcam Driver, most likely under " Imaging Devices"  and right-click and hit uninstall. 

Hope the above is helpful! 
If you need more help please write to support[@]animaze[.]us

97502845.review: As someone who needs glasses to see ANYTHING the eye tracking for facial expressions doesn't work for crap. I'm not sure if its just user error on my part but its not like i can remove my glasses or the glare from my computers screen on my glasses. if you need glasses to function well then this app wont work very well with you.
97502845.developer_response:
Hello Killer42895

There are several ways to address the glare issue you mention.

The key aspect is to remember no tracker can track what it can't see so if glare is blocking the webcam's view to your eyes then that needs to be addressed before proper tracking can be possible (in any setting).

Things to try for glare, in no particular order:

1. Adjusting the light sources in the room.
2. Adjusting the advanced tracking settings related to eyes in the software to filter more (or flat out ignore) eye-tracking and use procedural behaviours like "look at camera" instead of tracking (that's how most software is dealing with "unavoidable"  glare on glasses).
3. If most of the glare comes from just one source such as the monitor screen:  using a simple layer of inexpensive polarised film on top of the webcam, rotated to filter out the glare works wonders (and a large enough patch of polarised film should cost only a few dollars - no need for expensive photographic polarised filter lenses).
4.Using iPhone TrueDepth tracking, Tobii Eye tracker or infrared tracking instead of regular webcam tracking. (Animaze works with all of the above)  
5.Using anti-reflective lenses.

Hello T3h_Danger,

Thank you for the feedback and sorry for your experience with our support team member. We'll try to do better.

There seems to be some significant miscommunication here indeed as one does NOT need to start the import process over from 0 each time after testing the tracking in the app.

The Animaze Editor does support saving your work in its Resources folder and you can pick up from there later, and re-bundle and iterate how many times you want without starting from 0. There are rare edge cases where you might need to force a clean import, but that's not the regular workflow (ideally that should never happen) - if you have found how to reproduce such a case consistently we'd be happy to assist via email or via the discord server  (and we can also find what caused it and fix it).

Cheers!

92424499.review:
edit november 2021:
Haven't done vtuber stuff since july so I can't comment exactly on what changes have/were made. 
I would suggest checking all the updates from june or so onwards and making your own judgment 

edit june 28th:

they seem to be actually adding good features and updates so I am still optimistic. 

I can see how active and serious the developers are in making this product which is why it's a little sad to me that whomever they hired to do their financial planning for the future (I dearly hope it's not the devs themselves who decided some of these choices because they are typical at best, deceptive at worst) ruined this product. 

It is not bad. It works great. It even feels smoother and has less impact on my PC's performance compared to facerig, which is a huge resource hog. I didn't feel like I was hurting my framerate as much as I did with facerig.

Here are the problems. Here is how to fix this in one fell swoop and regain confidence in your users. There are many reviews that are negative, rightfully so, but I want to be a little more... constructive.

Firstly: the coin system is useless and no one cares about anything in it. There's nothing meaningful. I have the 1500 or 2000 or whatever from registering and having facerig I guess, and I bought a few things to try stuff, but... it's meaningless. I understand if it's being expanded upon regularly, but there is no reason to want to pay money for these objects that don't have any character, any aesthetic, are cookie cutter, when you can literally just use the money you'd pay for the subscription, cash shop, whatever, on a real avatar and use any of the other software available, or just facerig itself. 

Literally the only reason I could see for having a cash shop coinsystem like this is if the devs were releasing ~licensed content~, in partnership with some other intellectual properties, so that you can curb the cost of the licensed materials. I could see it being justified in that case. Only. 

Next, the convenience-heavy subscriptions I have tried to explain why each one is useless. 

https://i.imgur.com/CgGNgXM.png

How to fix this? After all, complaining with no suggestions is simply whining. 
~ I want the convenience to be built in. 
~ I want the subscription fees, or cash shop things, to be something you ease into- for instance, how pretty much the rest of this sort of market functions. They should be features and tools that advanced users can take the most advantage of, and not being any sort of expert in this software, I can't tell the devs what that should be, but asking the advanced users is the best way to start.
~ The fully functional, non-annoyance base software should be like the 'plus' subscription. From there, you can add in ways to pay so as to enhance what you are expressing to your viewers- after all, that's the entire point of this. Not funny video calls, not funny videos. It's about streaming, and for those of us who do not feel comfortable with a facecam to be able to express ourselves more thoroughly through our actions. Watching myself play a shooter was incredible; I didn't realize how expressive I was, how serious I looked, how smug I looked after good shots or good kills, whatever. How I look when I get confused. It's all different from real life, and it makes vtubing very fun and very intimate with viewers you previously may have only been able to connect with with your radio voice. 

~ Streamlabs is a good example of ways to monetize 'convenience' content without making you pay first to not be annoyed, then afterwards for materials.  (Maybe not. Updated 12/26/21))

~ If you don't have enough content made yet to fill up the shop, then stop wasting development time on the customizable awful looking avatars, and work on more effects, backgrounds, scenes, transitions, things that can be adjusted and edited. I really liked the little effects- the hearts and stuff are things I definitely want on my avatar. I would pay for a whole set of things like that. I see...  six? And two are terrible. 

https://imgur.com/a/oxxByrN here are examples of why I think these are great and should be expanded on. I know I can do this myself with OBS and other tools. But THAT'S the sort of feature that can be monetized, artist time can be spent on, is nondiscriminatory of avatar types since they could be for anyone, etc etc. 

There is a lot of potential being wasted in this software because of how it is being presented. 
I give this a pre-recommend because I am optimistic and hope in the future I won't have to change it. I will surely come back to this review in 6-12 months and then see where Animaze has gone. 

Thank you.

Even though it's free, be aware that this company uses shady business plans. The subsription may be cheap but for two reasons I will not recommend this. One, you cannot open a seperate avatar window without a subscription, so you are stuck with all the bloat (can be cropped away in the streaming software). Second, be aware streamers and content creators, if you make more than $500 a month you will have to pay an additional fee for commercial rights (lol), so *** ridiculous.
The first reason is actually the one holding me back from a subscription, such a basic vital feature locked behind a paywall, not a business modell I will support.

Furthermore, the face tracking is horrible, in 5 minutes I had to recalibrate more than 10 times because everytime I itch my face (or anything blocking the face) or turn my head to far the calibration fails to go back and a calibration must be done.
There's no way to have a casual pose or turn of head tracking so just be aware of some really weird animations and avatar bugs.

If you ask me, for a free app it's mediocre. For a Early Access I didn't expect more. Hopefylly this will stay in development considering they added aubscriptions into a Early Access software, smells cash grab a long way but I guess devs have to prove me wrong.
91921309.developer_response:
Hello,

Some of the information you mentioned is incorrect. Animaze has two subscription tiers: Plus and VIP. Everyone can use Animaze and stream with it without having to subscribe. However, once a streamer hits a monthly revenue of $500 or more, then that streamer will have to subscribe to the VIP tier. This, by no means, constitutes an additional fee since they were using the program for Free until then. 

In regards to the face tracking, it is important to remember that one must have good lighting and that the camera should be placed level with the streamer's face. If in the event of moving more than usual during one's streaming session, we have Advanced Tracking Configuration through which users can tweak settings or disable some tracking aspects, increase or decrease the range of the tracker when it comes to head, mouth, eyes and so on.

Regards,
David

89839618.developer_response:
Hello Face the FAIL-GINEER

We are sorry to hear you are experiencing this, but you are misattributing the  standard Windows10 behavior around newly installed webcams to Animaze.

Windows by default sets the most recently installed webcam device as the default webcam device. This is an OS level assumption that we cannot change. That is why after installing Animaze most webcam apps will try to source their image from the Animaze virtual webcam driver.

All you need to do is, after installing, just go in the Windows settings and simply set your default webcam device back to the physical device.

Animaze needs to install a virtual webcam device so you can broadcast and use it with Chat apps.

89773143.developer_response:
Hello doormouse,


We are sorry to hear that this was your experience with Animaze. It is fixable though.

From the sound of it, you don't like the tracking defaults (we agree the default settings cannot please everyone - the default in Animaze have been tuned for higher quality webcam sensors and more proper light setups than they were in FaceRig)  You can adjust them to fit your set-up though.


We're here to help if you'd let us.

There are FAQ's on animaze.us that teach you how to configure the software but you can also hop on Discord, share a video with your experience and we can give you tips and tricks on how to fix what is bugging you. 

GPU occupancy is configurable as well.

On a more personal note -  maybe the extensive feedback you sent didn't reach us or didn't reach the right person - we are a small team and things can slip through the cracks. Hop on the Discord, we're friendly.

Animaze has individual per expression adjustments and all the advanced settings you would need, (more than FaceRig). You never engaged with David from support on the topic, you just assumed that it wasn't there.



With mo-cap done with problematic lighting and grainy sensors, there is always a compromise to be made from responsive but jittery    to   smooth but laggy., but in most cases, a happy middle ground can still be achieved.

The Animaze defaults start with the idea that the mo-cap light setup and the image sensor quality are a bit higher than they were in Facerig. But you can change those defaults to match your set-up.

Cheers!


PS: If you want to stay on the free version as a power user, it is actually easy to crop the watermark with OBS. The watermark never goes over the center of the screen - easily croppable. 
Also we didn't put a time limit on the tracking on the free version - the broadcast timer is just on the vcam driver-  but you don't need the vcam driver if you use  OBS window capture.  
We do think all the dev work eventually deserves payment, but you can, if you insist, stay on the free tier forever as a power-user by using OBS.

The free tier is meant for more casual users, who just want to join a class as an avatar for the lul's, they usually don't mind the watermark or the time limit. 
You seem to be more of a power-user who wants to use Animaze for streaming, and we think a paid plan is fair for power-users.

89391501.developer_response:
Hello Merula

The free feature-set for all casual users, and the one dollar and seventy cents per month optional sub cost for the ever-expanding Animaze tech feature-set for power-users is, we trust, a fair offer.


We're sorry you feel this is greedy in some way, though most likely you too, if you are a streamer on Twitch, are asking your viewers to subscribe to you for five dollars a month so can continue making content. 
What are your viewers thinking about your selling strategy?


Ongoing support, feature development, and creating avatar content for many ongoing years (that we know the avatar community wants) is a service and cannot realistically be done long term unless we treat it as a service. 


We've tried the alternative with Facerig as a product back in 2014 and a few years in, the development had to stall - that approach just wasn't sustainable long-term. The avatar community taught us that lesson quite bluntly, over a few difficult years.
 
Ongoing dev work deserves a small ongoing payment - that is reality.
There is no need for expletives, and there is no greed involved, just sustainability.

Cheers!

89317232.developer_response:
Hello theshockcable,

We are sorry this is what you have experienced, however, you might have fallen prey to some intense misinformation in regards to "repackaged software".

Animaze is the 2021 successor to the 2015 Facerig (or 2020- and 2014 if you take into account Early Access launches). There's a six-year difference between the two. 
 
Animaze is not repackaged Facerig (any more than let's say The Witcher 3 is repackaged The Witcher 1). It has been actually re-built from the ground up.
 
There are some old avatars from the old FaceRig that have been brought over to the new platform due to popular demand from the community, but what we are working on the hardest, is the new tech and the new avatars.


We have had extensive communication on the matter on both the FaceRig Page and the Animaze Page.

Animaze is free to play for casual use- most casual users that just want to have a few laughs while attending a class, or have fun on a video call, don't ever have to pay a dime  (while Facerig had a mandatory payment for both casual users and power-users at the very start).
 
Power users (like streamers doing long streams) however will most likely want one of the paid tiers of Animaze.

Animaze uses a brand new cross-platform render engine. 
Animaze also has features that Facerig never had. To list a few:
-> iPhone tracking (via Wifi), 
-> Better webcam face tracking (that can even see when you're sticking out the tongue)
-> Persona Avatar Creator (allowing for thousand of avatar creation combinations),
-> Hybrid avatars ( new technology, never available in FaceRig),
-> Animaze Editor Tool (and avatar artist documentation).
-> Live2D animated backgrounds with overlays.
-> Two types of audio-based lip motion.

Soon to be released:
-> VRM support
-> Freeform Live2D parameter remapping.
-> Emotes support (also user-editable)
And more (stay tuned for the next update :)).

Animaze is still in Early Access (more things are being added each month).
 
Animaze like FaceRig supports importing your own characters too, it is an open creation platform  (the pool of avatars will grow as time goes by- Animaze has only been live for a few months, but you don't have to rely only on the stock avatars). However, the importing tools and documentation for Animaze are far superior to Facerig's.

Animaze is in Early Access and evolves each month based on user feedback, for instance, a new home screen interface will also go live in a few days, along with enhanced inferred body motion for Live2D avatars.  We even have a new Live2D parameter remapper in the Animaze Editor that will go live in April :)

Would we be wrong in assuming you are also not importing your Live2D model through the recommended way, through the Animaze Editor to first set up the metadata (render resolution, parameter mapping etc), and are using the fast-lane default import direct-to-app method, which makes a lot of default assumptions that might not be to your liking - and you assume that must be a hard limit?

Animaze is still evolving but already has settings that we trust would address most your concerns. We are working on surfacing these options in more intuitive ways :). We are also tweaking some of the defaults - for instance in the future the fast lane import for Live2D models will import by default at a higher resolution than what the Live2D avatar artist has set in the Cubism runtime file.


Alas, it is also okay if you chose to go a different route :).
 
We're confident that once Animaze is completed all its advantages will shine through! 
Cheers and best of luck!

88974174.developer_response:
Hello LOKingIV,

Sorry to hear you are experiencing these, the good news is both have quick solutions;

1. To hide the watermark there is a toggle in the settings that you need to set to "off". 
Animaze Menu>Settings>General>Hide Animaze Watermark

2.Avatar render resolution: 
Note: If the information below seems confusing you can always email us at support@animaze.us
 
Note that the Animaze PC app will by default display your Live2D model at the exact render size that you have set in the model files in Cubism, or in the Animaze Editor under "Render size" in Live2D Options, (during the import process). 

You can also further scale up or down the resolution of your avatar within Animaze by changing the “2D Avatar Render Scale” setting in the Animaze PC App but that won't go beyond 2x what you have set in the model files or Animaze Editor. If you want to go higher you need to set the base value to be higher, and you can do so when importing through the Animaze Editor.


The reason that is happening is because Animaze does use the best practice of reading the recommended render size set by the original artist from the Cubism Editor and does not by default override it with 8k (which is what is happening by default in other apps). 
Some software suites have chosen by default to ignore this setting and just override it with 8k, and that is why many artists now forget to set it, but the recommended best practice is to use this artist-set value.

You can edit it in Animaze too, but you need to import your avatar through the Animaze Editor path  do so (rather than use the fast lane direct-to-app import )

88080397.developer_response:
Hello Ryan,

I fear there's a big misunderstanding here, (your statement can actually be misleading):  Animaze Software and the Live2D Cubism editor serve quite different purposes  - they are not interchangeable. 

Animaze is where you use motion capture/tracking technology to animate/embody existing avatars (2D or 3D, provided by Animaze or imported from external art software) in real-time using your own face expressions and motions, for live-streaming video calls and such.  

The  Cubism Editor from Live2D is software where artists can create such 2D avatars, that you later can load up and use in Animaze.


By using Animaze with 2D avatars you are also actively supporting Live2D (including financially, if you chose to be a paying user of 2D content).
Holotech has collaborated with Live2D in various ways since 2015, they are our trusted and esteemed licensing partners and together we have worked to bring Live2D avatars to a wide audience.
 

Cheers!

87460708.developer_response:
Hello 2NightGaming,

We are sorry to see such harsh words, but before passing quick judgment please consider the following facts.

You are a power user looking for power-user features. There are also people just using the free version casually for fun with friends. The free version is perfect for that. Many of the casual users never feel the need to upgrade to a paid plan.




It is understandable how for power users the Free Tier might feel more limiting (like a trial), but for most casual people, it is a fun free product that they use when attending a class, or having a laugh with friends/ on a short stream. This even extends past the gaming world, for instance, grandparents who haven't seen their nephews in a long time due to Covid, wanting to read stories over Skype video-call as a character from the story via Animaze. 

Power users' use-cases (streaming longer hours / making a living out of streaming) are indeed better suited for a paid plan. 


The claim that Animaze is not different enough from Facerig overlooks a lot of features and facts.

- An in-app human character creator (Personas, nothing like this ever existed in Facerig) 
- A different, better tracking engine with far more tracking parameters
- 64 bit infrastructure (Facerig was always 32 only)
- Two distinct audio tracking methods (Facerig only had one)
- Radically different artist tools 
- Brand new render engine (OpenGL based, better suited for future cross-platform than the FaceRig DirectX approach)
- Brand new animation engine
- Hybrid avatars.
- Live2D animated backgrounds and overlays - with elements that can be tied to the tracking.
will stop here (but the list can go on, and not even starting the listing on the in-progress initiatives that are almost done & will be launched in March, like VRM/Vroid  support)

The fact that there are some old avatars popular with the community that our team has worked extra hard to port over from the old Facerig, and tried to make them look feel familiar is no reason to be dismissive of their efforts. You can ask anyone who tried porting their 3D avatar over themselves without assistance from our team - jumping from one engine to the other is not trivial - in spite of the significant work we put in simplifying the process). 

Animaze is not a copy of Facerig, any more than (to use a gaming comparison) the Witcher 3  is actually a copy of Witcher 2.

Only someone who only briefly looks on the surface before passing judgment might get that impression.

87231032.review: My webcam does not work anymore after I downloaded this. Can someone help me make my webcam work agian?
87231032.developer_response:
Hello Voszy!

Sorry to hear you are experiencing this

The solution is simple:
You simply need to go to the Windows Control Panel, in Devices and Printers and set your physical webcam as the default webcam on your system.


Why is this happening:
Whenever you install a new webcam driver, the Windows OS by default assumes that you want that as your "default webcam". 
In your case, the last installed webcam was the Animaze Virtual Camera driver, but you can change that setting by using the steps above.

This behavior is at OS-level and we cannot influence that. Windows assumes you will always want the most recent installed webcam set as the default webcam on your system. The fix is trivial though.

86654580.developer_response:
Hello HanSoloCambo 

Thank you for the detailed thoughts!

I will respond to some of them here in an itemized fashion but would love if you joined our Discord or email us at support@animaze.us so we can discuss more freely than in this format :).
If there was any bug affecting your coin inventory, we can for sure restore the coin inventory. Writing to support@animaze.us is the best path for that.


"It's kind of fun. But facial expressions are extremely limited..."

This is a common misunderstanding occurring when people are using the software without a calibration, or with a wrong calibration.
It sounds like either a proper calibration was not performed, or the audio-based lip tracking was turned on but configured wrong in terms of background noise threshold (or there is a new bug that is occurring in very particular situations - but so far the cause for that has almost always been improper calibration)
Always calibrate properly, and set the proper noise gate for background noise for audio, otherwise, it can misbehave as you described.

More details and tips and tricks on mo-cap setup are in the FAQ section on animaze dot us (writing it this way as web-links are not allowed here) 
/faq/animazedesktop/calibrateinanimaze
/faq/animazedesktop/tipsandtricksfortracking


"The avatar closes its mouth only when there's nobody facing the camera..."

Assuming a proper calibration was performed, this occurs only when you have audio lipsync turned on but with a really low, or no noise threshold, so all background noise from the microphone generates some lip motion/lip opening.

It is easy to get the avatar to fully close its mouth: all is needed is proper visual calibration and good audio tracking settings, (if audio tracking is also used). Alternately you can turn off audio tracking completely and rely on visual only (but a 60 FPS webcam providing a 60 fps input and 60 FPS tracking is almost mandatory for good lip motion in this case).


"Also we can update textures, but we don't have access to the obj of their avatars or at least a flattened wireframe. So it's basically impossible to do anything nice and pro. "

The in-app texture edits are indeed meant for more beginning users who are just learning the ropes. 
Importing fully custom avatars, from all professional tools (via common formats) is possible via the Animaze Editor. Full documentation is here.
 www . animaze . us / manual

"And export as obj / fbx for paid users would have been nice to be able to really customize those avatars. "

The run-time avatars are there for people with limited 3D knowledge who really want to use them as they come, and at most some minor edits.
 
For people who can edit fully OBJ and FBX models, and would know where to begin on how to generate a mathematically correct normal map for a pre-existing tangent space from a run-time model reverse-engineered into an editable OBJ/FBX source,  those people are very very few, and we always assume that had their own models to import rather than work on derivative assets.

If you are in that group, you can always contact us at support@animaze.us and tell us which models you would want the sources to, (because that's the exception rather than the norm so we have considered spending resources to build such a feature in the app  - that very few people would use -  would best be avoided). 

We love the ideas. Please drop by our Discord channel to chat! 
 discord . gg / e53h99z

Will provide some feedback just to one of them (because using high FOV on the render camera is possible, it just takes a bit of extra work as it was not the default).

.Ideas :
"- an option to change the camera's focal so that when the avatar bends forward, we can get a more powerful effect. As it is the camera nearly feels like an isometric viewport. "

Even our team is not necessarily of one mind on the matter of the default camera FOV. Artists building the 3D models were the ones that pushed for a low default FOV for the camera to have less perspective deformation (almost isometric). 
You can in the Animaze Editor create a background that uses a higher  FOV camera instead of the almost isometric look. (so you can get this effect).

Thank you again for all the feedback, and we can't wait to talk with you on Discord!




On the Edit: EDIT : "I paid for a year. My credits went up to 2000. After using the product for about an hour ? My credits went down to 1500. But I did NOT buy anything. Please advise."

The yearly subscription system for access to the more advanced tech features is not connected with the avatar marketplace and its currency system.
As far as I know, subscribing is not meant to award coins. I will double-check with the product team- maybe we had a recent development.
 
Art content purchases in the app are one-time purchases funded by gold coins. Gold coin purchases allows us to pay the artists.
Providing and updating/maintaining more advanced tech features is separate from art- that is an ongoing body of engineering work, funded via subscriptions - (and does not use gold coins). Subscribing to this service, allows to us pay the engineers.

Not sure what else can generate temporary gold coins increase up to 2000 from the default 1500 free coins, but we do award 500 free gold coins if you make a free Animaze account, so maybe it had something to do with that, rather than anything subscription related.

Casual user features are on the free plan (and that plan is free forever - it never expires).
Power-user features are on paid plans (20 USD per year unlocks all power-user tech features).

All paid plans are opt-in (we don't "charge people anyways"). 
The only people who pay are the ones who have explicitly chosen to pay, after deciding that the price is worthwhile for them.

You don't seem to have used the app for more than 6 minutes (and you were never billed for anything).  

Developing software costs money and it is fair to have a form of payment (we need to pay salaries to our engineers and artists to create and maintain the software and avatars). 

We've chosen to give free access to the casual use features, but that does not mean we are obligated to give everyone (including power users) free access to all features we're developing.

Cheers!

85416536.developer_response:
Hi,
Adding Animaze to your streaming configuration (stream software + game) will add some CPU/GPU load. Note that face tracking and high quality rendering come with the CPU and GPU resource cost, so if you are running a game at high quality graphics option, you may have frame drops.

There are some things that you can do to make Animaze footprint smaller on your setup:
1. use Animaze at a lower resolution, you can go as low as 960x540. I assume you are using Animaze as webcam view, so the view is already small.
2. use a lower setting in the game you are streaming, after all, you are basically streaming two games (resource wise)
3. use window capture instead of Animaze Virtual Webcam and disable Broadcast. There is an option to hide the interface.
4. limit Animaze's refresh rate to 24-30 fps. Go to General Options > Performance Tab.
5. Camera resolution needs to be low (General Options > Resolution).

84551220.developer_response:
Hi,
After you install Animaze and its Virtual Microphone driver, the driver may become the default output and input source in Windows. Here is how to change it back:
1. Go to Sound Settings in Windows (press Windows key and type “Sound Settings”)
2. Use the drop-down list under “Output” to select your output speakers
3. Use the drop-down list under “Input” to select your input source (actual microphone).
