82728807.review:
I feel as if people aren't giving this software enough credit, for what I'm getting and the yearly fee etc. I think it's really worth it, I haven't had any issues with it and the tracking is certainly much better than Facerig, it can actually see my eyes through my glasses, unlike Facerig where if it loses track of my eyes for even a millisecond, it stops capturing my whole face and I have to take my glasses off for it to pick me back up again.

I think this software's got a heck of a lot of potential, I only wish for audio based lip sync and I'm set with this product.

I'd rather pay $20 a year than buy an iPhone just for the face recognition camera alternatives...

Edit: I've come back to this review because I feel I wasn't descriptive enough in why I believe this software was poorly credited.

After reading plenty of reviews, that just happened to be mostly negative, it seems the main focus is on the money placed for the additional features of a free to use software... I understand that people tend to have a different perspective on where they should be putting their money, but with a software with a near perfect face tracking programming (imo) I feel as if the cost for this is an investment for the people that are using this to become Vtubers or something similar. I've tried researching alternative softwares to Facerig in the past due to their original software 'Facerig' had an issue with picking up my face while I'm wearing glasses half the time, and discovered that there isn't a broad variety of alternatives for just a PC and webcam, most of them are solely dependant on an iPhones face tracking camera features. Ontop of all this the cost is only $20 for a whole year! so what if you have to sacrifice like what... a single takeout meal to afford it, it's a whole year at that price, if Vtuber or whatever is something you really want to do, it's not bad to invest in quality. 

I'm not sure what the devs reason for the subscription might be but from my perspective it's an attempt of a consistent stable income for a dev team that needs a consistent income, if Facerig is the only software they've done in the past and that's what they're best at, their sales have probably dropped a considerable amount by now, it's a 5+ year old software now and most the marketting for that softwares probably eaten up by now, things can only trend for so long... I could be wrong on this part but I do see where the devs are coming from, I'm not sure if they were just unlucky with getting the target audience they were looking for but it all just seems all the flak it's been given is quite harsh to me.

onto actual product review, The software works great, I've had no issues with the tracking, or with any imports, in which I must say I'm greatful for the amount of import support it has, after tampering with alternative apps they tend to be a bit strict on what's usable and what's not, this software seems to have quite a wide amount of file support. I've already written about the microphone input to mouth feature would be nice and read the devs response, thank you very much devs. The only other issue I had but have found a fix for is using this while playing games, I've noticed I get a considerable frame drop on Animaze while I'm playing high end video games (I'm using a nvidia 2070s if anyone's considering my card might be the issue) but I have figured out 2 fixes, 
1. frame lock the game, I play on 144hz uncapped most times I play games, but if I have animaze open I lock the frames to 60fps, it seems my PC prioritises pushing all it's resources into the videogame otherwise. 
2. Set the Animaze executable proccess to High Priority, because of previous statement. Other than this, I'm very happy with this software and I'm looking forward to future improvements!

81644623.developer_response:
Hi, we would like to investigate your issue to see how we can fix it. 
Please  send the logs via email at support[at]animaze[dot]us.

The first and most important files are:
To get them go to where you installed Steam, for example: C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\steamapps\common\Animaze\Data\Animaze.log
Remember that log files get rewritten each time the app is opened, so in order to get the correct files do not restart the app until you've saved the logs.

Also important are the DxDiag files, to get them use the hotkey: Win+R → enter "dxdiag" --> press "OK" --> press "Save"

81365578.review:
UPDATED REVIEW 15/12/2020:

This review was originally made when it costed money to import models. While getting rid of that hasn't solved the entire issue, I can at least say that this puts the software in a position where it's friendlier to the average user. My recommendation now is to get and use the software, and show your support for one-time payments by only importing models and downloading from the workshop. I am still happy to pay a one-time purchase for this software instead of this business model instead of this premium currency nonsense. So, while I now can whole-heartedly recommend this software, I urge anyone and everyone to voice support of abolishing the premium currency model in a way that's constructive and devoid of harassment. Do not, and I repeat, do not buy any of their premium currency. The studio will follow where the money is.


OUTDATED REVIEW:

Please let me start by saying that there is some real true potential here. I had the first facerig for some time, and it took me hours to calibrate it to something workable. I nonetheless found it to be a remarkable piece of software, and still do. The work and effort put in by all the developers of this software cannot go understated, and I truly do thank everyone's hard work for making this software.

I have now tried this software and the setup was vastly more simple. The UI is extremely clean and intuitive, and the facial tracking algorithms feel absolutely cutting edge. Even with no calibration at all, it was miles better than the first facerig, and after a bit of fine tuning it was practically 1-to-1 with my own facial expressions. This is a truly remarkable achievement.

But, alas, I cannot recommend it, and the worst part is that it was due to a decision that likely were not even the developer's fault. This was a business decision. And make no mistake, anyone who throws shade at the developers who had no control over this business decision are just as big of a problem. The business decision in question is, of course, making this free to play with premium currency. The business decision made here could only have come from one of two possibilities: Either they didn't know that it would generate such awful PR, or they simply didn't care. Whatever the case, there is no excuse for it.

Charge me $30, Charge me $40, Charge me $50, I don't care. The truth remains that I (and clearly many others) would much prefer to give a one-time payment than this heinous business model which should never have left the mobile gaming industry (and in my opinion shouldn't exist there either). Some may think it generosity to start us out with currency, but that is exactly how they get you: enough for a few models, but leaves you wanting more. It's so much easier to justify all those smaller purchases over a longer period of time, and this is not even including the subscription service. If locking those features behind a paywall really means so much to the business reps at Holotech, at least do us the decency of having a standard and pro version of the software instead of this.

I have followed the development of facerig very closely and was very excited for Animaze, but this is a complete let-down. I can only apologise to all the developers who worked so hard on this, only to be let down as much as I was by greed. If the studio abandons this business practice and goes back to just charging a set price to get access to everything, I will not only change my review in a heartbeat, but buy it the second I get the chance.

80564835.review:
Software is mediocre and payment model is a scam.  

They prey on people not knowing how to get around the payment. But they support you doing workarounds to having to pay and making it free. 

Want to import your own models? It costs $1 per model which isnt very much. HOWEVER, they also present you with the option to upload your models on the workshop for free, some people may be put off to sharing their models and creations though. The catch, and they dont make it very advertised, you can make your workshop item private. Which leads me to then wonder. Why charge $1 at all? The only reason is to take advantage of people not familiar with how the workshop works.  

They also restrict how long you can stream/broadcast using the software and make you pay to unlock this. HOWEVER they also support for free, bypassing this if you use OBS or something. Again, this only preys upon people less technically savvy or that dont know how to do this. WHY make something PAID but also support it as being free if you figure out the workaround that you claim to officially support? VERY QUESTIONABLE business practice. 

Free content available is minimal. And content you need to buy coins and then purchase is rather low quality as well. If you want to see hoow this does with 2D characters anime and such, its locked behind spending coins to get the extra people.  

And then we have subscriptions. $10 or $20 depending if you own the previous software with annual fee. You will never own this software in any capacity and honestly I hate this type of sales model. Especially with something that just has bad UI and doesnt offer much content worth a subscription cost.  Id rather no subscriptions and instead just pay for characters, props, animations and backgrounds as I want them. 

Big step backwards if you ask me.

It's good for what it does. Just make sure you have a powerful computer, otherwise performance is going to be the bane of your existence.

They've since fixed many of their glaring issues, and have reached feature parity (if not, gone above and beyond) the original FaceRig app.

From the original review, they have since:
1. Added perpetual; one-time purchases to their yearly version updates/releases
2. Removed some of the annoyances that made their software hard/impossible to use without paying
3. Ironed the whole thing out, and made it better.
4. Not applicable anymore. Also, one-time purchase is around the same price as if you had the license. Just that it was a terrible value proposition two years ago.
5. With those blots removed, I'd say it's worth it to pay to not have to deal with 'jank', especially when you're a stupid idiotic end user (us devs are smart; I managed to get to their baseline as one person then gave up two years ago; didn't have the will/bother to become a competitor).
6. You can now bypass the pay-per-avatar model by buying a one-time purchase pass, or obtaining one by staying on the subscription. Think of it as JetBrain/Atlassian's rent-to-own model (you get a perpetual license after staying one year continuously).

At the time of the original review; I should've just wait.
And at the same time, they made the mistake of rushing and releasing software with terrible restrictions/monetisation BEFORE it was even ready for prime-time. Definitely needed another year or two of development.

80083626.review: can only access one character and that is it.. kinda annoyed since i am paying for a broken program
80083626.developer_response:
Hi SkyePaws,

Sorry that you have encountered some issues. 

There are three potential fixes for this issue. If none of them work, please email us at support[at]animaze.us with your logs (SteamLibrary folder.... steamapps\common\Animaze\Data\Animaze.log) and dxdiag (hotkey: Win+R → enter dxdiag) so we can investigate further. 
 
1. Time Sync  and geo-blocking
(a) Make sure that your system clock is automatically synced (not manually set or synced to a different time zone)
(b) Make sure that your anti-virus is not geo-blocking Germany (we have a server there)!
 
2. Menus are moved off screen
This might happen because Animaze remembers the absolute position you placed the panels. For example, if you open the app at default size 1280x720, and maximize it, it goes to 1920x1080. Then you open the avatars gallery, move it to the far right of the app screen. Reopen the app, it’s now at 1280x720, if you click on avatars, it opens at the position saved for the 1920x1080 size of the window app, hence you don’t see the gallery at all, and need to maximize it again. 
The workaround is: go to Steam\steamapps\common\Animaze\Data
and delete AppPreferences.json. Note, this will reset some app options to default.
We will add a better fix in the coming releases. Thanks for bringing this bug to our attention.

3. Something else went wrong 
(a) Uninstall the app in your Steam Library
(b) Delete the Animaze folder from your Windows files Steam\steamapps\common
(c) Reinstall Animaze

Warm regards,
Allyson

79795068.review:
I was looking forward to this release for a long while, especially after supporting FaceRig on Kickstarter many moons ago. 

The tracking itself is really good, but I don't see much reason at the moment to upgrade from my copy of FaceRig. One time purchase, for full functionality.

The subscription service itself doesn't exactly bug me, but since there's pretty much no way for me to convert a commissioned FaceRig avatar to Animaze right now, thinking I'll stick to my copy of FaceRig for now.

If they manage to implement an easier way to import FaceRig avatars, or even just standard humanoid 3D objects to Animaze, I'd upgrade in a heartbeat, especially with the mobile app functionality.



EDIT:
I genuinely appreciate the developers getting back to me that they've received this feedback. Animaze itself is a solid program, and I had a lot of fun with it testing the beta!

I just want to go ahead and clarify that although my review has "Not Recommended" on this, that's not necessarily a reflection on how well the program itself "plays".

During the beta, I ran into very few bugs and saw some immediate visual and functional improvements over FaceRig.

However, in the case of myself, and many others I know that use commissioned 3D avatars, I wouldn't recommend upgrading quite yet. 

Thank you again, devs for listening to the community, and even implementing small changes that were seen after listening to the feedback on the beta!
79795068.developer_response:
Thank you Ace of Hearts Fox,

This is super useful feedback.

We do have documentation and support python scripts for converting old 3D models to the new format up on the website, but you are correct, there currently is no super-easy way to convert old 3D models from the old engine to the new engine (just 2D ones are super easy). We will try to improve that process as time goes by.

It was a tough decision but as large chunks of the old engine for FaceRig were externally licensed and they were not getting any more updates (the team behind that engine had disbanded),  FaceRig was frozen in time.

The silver lining is that Animaze's core has been re-written in-house so that our users would ideally *never* have to deal with these kinds of migration pains again after this one.

Standard humanoid imports are also on the roadmap.

79761170.review:
I used to play around with FaceRig and was an early supporter, and Animaze feels like an update to FaceRig. For a game that had no major updates for years before Animaze, it feels like Animaze was supposed to be an update to the original, but the devs wanted to hide it behind a subscription-based wall and in-game currency. Yeah, you could use it for free, but all of the features like importing a model are locked behind this wall. You want the models in game too? You have to buy them with in-game currency and micro-transactions. It just feels like FaceRig with a brand new coat of paint to capitalize on not only the sales of FaceRig but the subscription based service. It feels like a dirty low blow to the supporters and to the community, and it's a shame the developers went this direction instead of updating FaceRig, which has felt and looked unfinished since it's release 5 years ago.

I didn't think I would come back to this review, but I've been playing around in the software since it's release and things have gotten worse. The first time I tried Animaze I could connect my iPhone X camera through the Animaze app to my computer to use the 3-d tracking rather than a webcam. Today when I entered the app and tried to do this it was hidden behind a paywall. This is sad, because it means that the developers are trying their hardest to take the most-used options that were originally free and to use it to incentivize people into using the subscription-based service. It's a scummy practice that is not working in their favor, and if I could change from a "not recommended" to "don't even give it your time to glance at it", I would.

From someone who backed FaceRig on IndieGogo years ago...this software feels like a slap in the face.

+ program seems to update a bit smoother, when it updates properly.
- movements, when not smooth, are jagged and janky. Much worse than FaceRig.
- still going with that 90 minute broadcast timer that was spoken against in such a high number.
- free version watermark moves corners *every 3 seconds* to be *as visually disruptive as possible*.
- in-program windows can't be closed or hidden, taking away from the alternative of "capture a portion of the window instead of broadcasting".
- sitting still often makes the avatar bug out and do its own thing, either rapidly jittering or "talking".
- audio-based lip sync is no longer a thing.

For a program that's supposed to be a successor...it's certainly doing things a lot WORSE when it's *supposed* to be an improvement.

If you don't have FaceRig, get it when it's on sale before it goes away.
If you can't deal with FaceRig or see this after FaceRig has been taken down...go with an alternative unless HoloTech comes to their senses and fixes this.

There is *ZERO INCENTIVE* to pay a subscription fee for a program that does no better than free alternatives, and actually does WORSE than its predecessor. Even with the FaceRig "discount" on the first year of subscription...it's not worth it.

79576914.developer_response:
Hi,
After you have installed Animaze and its afferent Virtual Microphone driver, this driver could become the default output and input source in Windows. Here is how to change it back: 

1. Go to Sound Settings in Windows (press Windows key and type “Sound Settings”)
2. Use the drop-down list under “Output” to select your output speakers
3. Use the drop-down list under “Input” to select your input source (actual microphone).

Dxdiag - press Window key + R, type dxdiag, hit run, save all of the information in a text file.

79479222.review:
There's a lot of negative reviews but I don't really see what's the problem. But I'm a tech person, so maybe that's why.

Let's see with my tech eye what others have said:
> subscription plan + fun features hidden behind it
You don't have to buy it. You get most of the features for free.

Subscription is pretty normal in those times - Adobe does it, Microsoft does it... - do you really expect to pay once and get updates for literally years? And get superduper new features for engine that was revolutionary at its time but cannot be easily extended? (Someone actually did say in their review that there are features devs "promised" "for years"...)
So base product is for free, and superduper features are for subscribers - that way you get your superduper stuff and devs and animators still get paid for it. Sounds fair.
The subscription is literally 4 dollars for a month. And less than 2 dollars a month if you pay for a whole year. You get one year for the price of Facerig+Live2D (Animaze has Live2D build-in). And half that if you had Facerig. Again sounds fair.

> can't stream for more than 90 minutes without subscription
Facerig was always like that - because you paid for it anyway. And professional streamers (earning more than x amount) were always meant to buy the extended license for use. But now you can also use it for free if you don't need additional features. Seems like a good deal.

>can't install their own avatar without sub or one-time payment of $1
Workshop is still free, you pay only for avatars that are only yours. And it's logical - if you have your own private avatar, you're a pro user, so you pay for it.

Also, did anyone notice that most negative reviews have 0.1-0.2h on play time? That's 10 minutes, it seems like judging by the cover...

-----
My own reviews:

Let's start with the fact that I watched Facerig when it first was developed. I wasn't a follower, just sometimes someone posted about it and I would binge watch/read new info. Facerig was revolutionary at its time.
It wasn't until years later that I could buy it and play with it (money doesn't grow on trees and I wasn't planning on using it a lot, so I waited till I had some spare money).
And now I have the new shiny product, still work in progress. Fun to compare.

And as a dev myself, working mostly on backend, I understand that technology changes fast and old code can't always be adjusted. Writing new version from scratch is tiring and you don't do everything the same way (because what would be the purpose of rewriting it?). I can see that the team managed to do this well. 
Of course it's still Early Access, it released as EA literally today, but I see a great potential for it (newly written code with all the knowledge you got through years? easy to maintain and extend).

Comparison:

Graphics:
Revamped avatars. With revamped and fuller customisation. Colours and shadows are adjusted, allowing for more freedom - Facerig got me playing with a lot of bright colours because clothing shading was always "on" - now the default colours are more muted and their parameters play a role in shading (making full-saturated colours really neon popping, which wasn't doable in Facerig)
Props - so far we only got some head props, but the level of detail is very nice. They sit very nicely - all default setting feel really natural, even though I'm putting hats and glasses on canines... Although I noticed some weird behaviour with scaling on some props - but it's normal in EA. The advanced options allow you to adjust the position basically in any way you want (you basically adjust image's position matrix itself - you couldn't have more detailed settings!).
Backgrounds - also smaller number, some new, some similar to Facerig's. What I noticed is revamped lighting. In some Facerig backgrounds, the lighting was either too low (why was avatar in classroom so dark, comparing to the bg itself?) or too bright (why was photo studio bg literally glowing?). And unnatural when moving avatar around (shift+right mouse button for turning the background). Now it feels right, you don't have to adjust the light.

Facial recognition:
I have droopy eyelids. My eyes always look small. And that made it hard for Facerig to see them.  Facerig would literally flicker my eyes - not even blink because it was so fast. Animaze doesn't do that. Even with default capture, without neutral face calibration. Even if I squint my eyes. Even if I shade my eyes from light - as long as they stay visible, it works!
If face is partially obstructed or even sideways(!), it's still well recognised and followed.
OH MY GODS. I found the tracking settings. You can change range of tracking and current reading on that scale is visible - so you can just make a face and adjust to that (eg jaw opening - even when my jaw is hurting, I can't make it go to the default upper bound). The number of options here is breathtaking. Eg separate settings for brow down and up, separate settings for smiling, frowning, side-to-side, only mouth corners... so this also mean the animations for those can be different for avatars, making the faces more natural. 
I noticed another difference when playing with mouth/jaw settings: lips vs teeth. It's not just mouth tracking. Select avatar with nice teeth (coronavirus Cory has seemingly healthy teeth and really flexible mouth to test all faces you can make) and open mouth with lips covering your teeth vs open them normally vs open them with showing as much teeth as you want, look how the upper lip of your avatar changes.

Performance:
Animaze, no matter what I do (without recording), takes around half a gig of RAM (up to 650MB). I lauched Facerig for comparison (and to add some details above) and it uses less RAM (~450MB with more when switching avatars) but more processing power (2x more CPU usage for me when doing basically nothing when writing this, Task Manager in view). This means, the new tech and optimisations are amazing. And that it shouldn't lag you.

-----
In short:
Natural lighting and animations, tracks your face well.
Good UI (I hated Facerig's UI, it was so weird!)
Free version will fit most usecases, especially in today's times of casual video calls to "meet" with friends despite pandemic.
Works well even for Early Access.

79475286.review:
Given what other software is available at this price point and the business model of the developers, I cannot recommend this software. As expected with FTP software, the functionality of the software is very limited. Users start with a handful of usable models and a small allowance to purchase more. Importing your own models costs 99 cents per import (unless you purchase a subscription) and currently doesn't have an option to use in-software currency to import. Without a subscription, the broadcast feature is measly 90 min, laughable by standards for both streaming and video call. Further, any broadcast in the free version includes a roaming watermark. It would be easy enough for someone to crop this out in obs, but for those using this for video calls, this is a big deterrent. 

Aside from the abysmal business model, I have a few issues with the workflow and organization. My biggest gripe within this category is the fact that the software install an additional 3 audio drivers for use with their in-software voice modifiers, a feature that I never intended and never intend to make use of. For some people this may not be too big of a deal, but as someone who has both a VR headset and an audio interface (and as a result 6 different drivers), having my default driver overridden by a bloat driver (even after uninstall) drives me up the wall. As for the UI, some may find it clean and simple, I find it dumbed-down and stifling. The controls are divided into 3 separate sub-windows (one for output, one for input, and one for models and voice) and are freely movable throughout the preview window. They are not however, dockable nor do they collide with each other. I much prefer the menus of a program like PrPrLive or VUP as they provide more functionality in their UIs. Another thing to note: the default font size is [b]ENORMOUS[/b] and makes the space feel cluttered.

I'll cede that this application has great facial tracking, however I cannot recommend this given what other software is freely available. I would much rather use a one-time payment software as opposed to a subscription for how sparingly I would end up using this. I never owned FaceRig and I'm glad. Do not get this software. In the meantime, I will be using PrPrLive or VUP.

79436005.review:
PROS
+ Better UI than Facerig.
+ "Free".
+ Has tongue recognition, whereas Facerig doesn't.

CONS
- Terrible facial recognition.
- My avatar is like Tweek Tweak from South Park, he keeps twitching. I am not moving.
- Terrible lip and tongue recognition.
- Still no hand/arm animation (So... what's the point of using Animaze then?).
- Does NOT allow you to add or remove facial tracking points.
- Microphone does not work with the recording (I have a $300 webcam), despite it being the default via Windows.
- No ways for you to modify the input in Animaze itself for the recording.
- Playback HAS to be modified to your actual speakers afterwards 
   since Animaze changes it to dummy Animaze speakers when Animaze is in use.
- Microtransactions (Because of the above, seriously? If it was a better product, I wouldn't mind as much).


CONCLUSION
I don't know who they were listening to honestly when they said they listened to the user base. This is NOT better than Facerig. It's the same thing in a better looking UI which works well and is intuitive if anything. Unless they improve the functionalities radically, stay away at all cost (not too hard to do at zero dollars). I was planning on creating a character with Animaze... that is until I started using it. 

Instead, I will use actual live props instead (featuring yours truly). At least, I know I won't fidget, and the facial tracking points will work one hundred percent! The question is how to create that character as I spend actual money on masks etc. Didn't wanna have to do that, but oh well.

This is cashgrab FaceRig. I appreciate it being a free and more sound version of its ancestor, but these are all the things you CAN'T do without PAYING FOR A FREE SERVICE:
- Import avatars, backgrounds or props
- Use your webcam for more than 90 minutes
- Stream at 60 FPS
- have advanced movement tracking
- Remove their watermark
- Have a dedicated capture window
- Use your iPhone to track your face
- Export videos as MP4 files
- Have early access to other features (this one is understandable)
- Use their avatars or your own via their app without permission

The fact that you have to give money to upload your own avatar to use it for more than 90 minutes with a 60fps camera is just dumb. It's a big middle finger to content creators and people who want to get into content creation. How did you mess it up this badly? Obviously this is only an Early Access build, but you're flipping off all the people who would want to support you. The average person isn't gonna pay $100 a year to make content on your platform. 79420435.review:
Animaze is very user friendly for someone new to face-tracking software.
You can use it in so many programs (Zoom, OBS, SLOBS etc.)
In just a few clicks, you can be a funny avatar.
You can even use your phone as a camera.

Compared to the predecessor Facerig, the tracking is far superior.  The advanced tracking options let you fine tune it, even down to the left vs right sides. While many Facerig avatars did not make the migration, there are new avatars available. The avatar customization is now very very easy, but lacks some of the features that made Facerig's avatars easy to make "your own".

The addition of animations is very nice, but I see a missed opportunity to add standard abilities to many (waving, etc). My favorite Machy only has one animation.

While Facerig was a one-time purchase, the new pricing model may not be ideal for all.  It is free-to-play, which let's you try it out, and fully functions for fun or content creation.  The "planned" Avatar Storefront for External Artists is VERY exciting.  It has always been a challenge to get models / props, and being able to shop within the app itself would be HUGE. I have been begging for year to let us pay for additional props.

79409302.review: I have been counting the days for this release and even as an Early Access release I was not disappointed whatsoever, as is the case sometimes when a title comes out as Early Access. Can\t ask for anything better than that.  The software absolutely lives up to whats promised and actually steps beyond that.  Quite a crowd of Facerig owners sitting around in chat waiting for the drop and after some dead silence while they too a look, the impression was that it was amazing!  It was even working for those of use with glasses which had been a problem with the facerig original.  Animation is tremendously smooth and the calibration for the avatar animations is such and improvement over facerig which was not ever as user friendly or intuitive as it could have been,  This is the avatar animation software that content creators have wanted and been looking for and its simply said, totally affordable!  I mean free is pretty affordable, but there are in app purchases or very low cost subscriptions.   And looking at their roadmap for just the next period of time through Early Access what is coming is going to be amazing!  The avatar customization has really jumped up in tech since face right and you now have some many more options to make your avatar unique. Absolutely was worth waiting for!

79408906.review:
Honestly I have mixed feelings about this. I love how the animations are better and have proven to be superior to facerig, but what I truly hate about this is that like most apps/buisness focused apps it uses a subscription based method for payment rather than paying for a full version directly. It's great to see how far this program has evolved and where it's at now but again, the subscription system is going to piss off a lot of people and in return might turn away people than make them use it more. Also the coins system in this is another obvious cash grab, something that most mobile games would do to "boost your experience" with a specific app.

What really baffles me is that you can't even stream in the highest quality even for 30 minutes without you paying for a subscription. You must pay to stream your avatar full time and to broadcast it to wherever you're using it on, specifically SLOBS or OBS since some streamers, including myself will use that as a replacement for our facecams (No proper camera, not comfortable with showing face, etc.). Also should note you can't stream anything from this app in 60 fps unless you PAY to do it. If you're looking on streaming with this on Twitch or YouTube, then Facerig will probably be your better option. As great as this new successor might be, I'm sorry to say that you'll have a better shot with Facerig if anything.

79408717.review:
Update 3/14/21
Need a Live2d avatar? Vtube studio.

Need 3d avatar? Vseeface, Luppet, whatever else. There isn't enough value added here in any way to use Animaze over them.

EARLY ACCESS? YA DONT SAY?
1. Every audio device on my pc stops working on launch, requiring me to restart OBS, Discord, and anything else that was running at the time.
2. I have to pay to even see if my personal avatar is any good, and at the moment, took my money and gave me nothing. No file upload dialog, -$1 in my steam wallet.

EDIT 12-02-2020
-tl;dr there are better choices of software available right now that come with less pain.

-I received my upload slot but my Facerig avatars don't work. They appear as invisible and their documentation apparently doesn't lead you through the process well enough. 
-I tried to export a newer version at a lower resolution and import it into Animaze, without any of the Facerig specific config files present. 
-This time the avatar appears, but it doesn't move. 
-Using the editor I EVENTUALLY FIGURED OUT how to get the avatar to show (the stupid frog apparently obstructs anything you add if you follow the instructions on the FAQ) and found that all of the correctly named parameters - per their own documentation, are all mapped as unknown.
-Remapped the relevant params per the FAQ and exported as a bundle .avatar and re imported. PLEASE NOTE YOU WILL HAVE TO BE VERY CAREFUL ABOUT WHERE YOU LOAD THE AVATAR FROM. Each time you touch it, there is going to be your original source folder, then a NEW folder Animaze makes in its own directory and ANOTHER folder it makes in the editors directory and you better make sure you're saving it to the one you're sure of.
-Avatar moves now but I have to finish remapping a dozen params for some reason, and then make sure all of my expressions even work.

*****After writing the part above, I found out the problem is my Live2D export was 8k. Apparently while thats OK in Facerig or OTHER software, Animaze plain old wont display anything greater than 4k. Sure would have been nice if that was documented. Imagine being an artist in 2020 and still drawing on a 2048x2048 canvas for something you're expecting thousands of people to look at closely on a stream.

Will add more once the saga continues.

79408200.review:
Animaze is a new program from the makers of facerig where with the help of accurate facial tracking you can be a virtual character during video calls or live streams or just to mess around during a google zoom meeting, there are so many fun things you can do with this.

Since video calling is very useful and widely used in the times we are currently in, I can only recommend that you try animaze.
Grandparents can surprise their grandchildren with an avatar or vice versa.

The facial tracking makes lines on the webcam image over the edge of your face, around your eyes, mouth, nose, eyebrows and lines from your nose to your upper lip.
Everything in its entirety ensures very precise tracking of your face and facial movements.
In any direction, as long as part of the face is in the sight of the facial tracking, this will nicely portray the movements on the avatar.

In Animaze you will recognize avatars from facerig, but you will also get to know a good number of new avatars, take for example the marijuana avatar, perfect for 'Tegridy streams'.
You will also be able to buy coins to unlock additional avatars, such as the marijuana plant or president trump and many many others.
The toilet paper roll is one of my favorites.

You can also customize all avatars with different colors, bigger or smaller head or other body parts,
you can give them funny hats or glasses and other things.
You can also adjust the background with photos from in the program or custom photos or even custom videos.
The avatars also have animations but this is not that extensive for the time being.

It's also possible to upload custom avatars but this isn't free, although it isn't expensive also.
Normally there will also be a steam workshop, and these avatars will be free to use for everyone.

Amazine also offered subscriptions that give you extra useful options, including unlimited custom avatars
you can also use your iPhone in this way to use as a face tracker via the Animaze app.

You can also record or broadcast directly from the program or take a screenshot with a green screen at the back so that you can use the avatar for photos.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IV2P3xOUYDs
